title: Detection of CD8+ T cell-mediated immune responses to bacterial infection in mice

Step-by-step method details
Evaluation of endogenous antigen-specific CD8+ T cell production and expansion in vivo by LmOVA
Timing: 7 days
Bacteria Listeria monocytogenes (L. monocytogenes) is a gram-positive intracellular pathogen whose clearance requires CD8+ T cell immunity. Recombinant L. monocytogenes expressing a full length of ovalbumin protein are named LmOVA. Through T cell receptor-specific recognition of ovalbumin peptide residues 257–264 (OVA257-264), LmOVA is able to induce the conversion of a fraction of CD8+ T cells into antigen-specific cells (Yang et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]).
Here, mice are immunized with LmOVA for 7 days. Splenocytes are isolated and stained with antibody to detect the CD8+ T cells which specific response to OVA and the cytokine production. The Scheme of this experiment is shown in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A.

Preparation of LmOVA before mice immunization
Spin down 5 × 105 CFU of LmOVA bacteria (per mouse) at 3000 g for 10 min at 25°C.
Wash LmOVA twice with 1 mL of phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) and centrifuge at 3000 g for 10 min at 25°C.
Discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the LmOVA precipitate with 100 μL PBS. Intravenous injection (i.v.) of LmOVA into mice (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).

Obtain organs On day 7, use CO2 for mice euthanasia and collect spleens and livers (in general, bigger spleens are observed if the corresponding mice are infected with LmOVA (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]E). The surgical procedure to harvest the organs is as follows.
Mice treatment with CO2 for euthanasia.
Mice are sprayed with 75% ethanol. This step will reduce the probability of the cells being contaminated by bacteria.
Spleen collection (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C):
Place the mouse on its side with one of its limbs facing outward.
Use forceps and surgical scissors to cut a small incision in the outer epidermis of the mouse, as shown in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C.
Use the new forceps and surgical scissors to make a small incision in the inner epidermis of the mouse.
Cut gastro-splenic ligament with surgical scissors and forceps to separate the spleen from the stomach.
Put the spleen in a 6-well cell culture dish with 2 mL PBS for next step.
Liver collection (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D):
Place the mouse on ventral surface as shown in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D and secure limbs using needles.
Use forceps and surgical scissors to cut abdominal outer epidermis of mouse.
Use the new forceps and surgical scissors to make an incision in the diaphragm of the mouse.
Carefully separate the liver from the diaphragm.
Put the liver in a 6-well cell culture dish with 2 mL PBS for next step.
Preparation of the splenocytes
Timing: 25 min
Place a 70 μm cell strainer on a 50 mL tube.
Put a mouse spleen on the 70-μm cell strainer and homogenize using the rubber end of a syringe with 2 mL PBS.
Flush and wash the strainer with another 2 mL PBS.
Spin down the spleen homogenate at 400 g at 4°C for 10 min.

Resuspend the precipitate with 1 mL Red Cell Lysis at 25°C for 5 min to eliminate red cells.
Add 9 mL PBS into the tube to end the red cell lysis process, and spin down splenocytes at 400 g for 10 min at 4°C.
Resuspend the cell precipitate using 1 mL PBS and put on ice for next step.
Antigen-specific CD8+ T cell staining
Timing: 50 min
Antigen-specific CD8+ T cell staining (MHC class I tetramer (Kb/OVA257-264) staining) using FITC anti-mouse CD8a Antibody, PE anti-mouse/human CD44 Antibody, and BV421 anti-MHC class I tetramer (Kb/OVA257-264) antibody.
Take 20 μL splenocytes into a 1.5 mL EP tube with 500 μL PBS and spin down at 1200 g for 5 min at 4°C.
Mix the staining antibodies with PBS+3% Fetal Bovine Serum(FBS). (Final concentration: BV421 anti-MHC class I tetramer (Kb/OVA257-264) antibody 2.5 μg/mL; PE anti-mouse/human CD44 Antibody 1 μg/mL; FITC anti-mouse CD8a Antibody 2.5 μg/mL).
Add 50 μL volume of antibody cocktail to each sample and keep on ice for 40 min avoid from light.
Wash the cells twice with 600 μL PBS.
Finally, resuspend the cell pellet with 400 μL PBS, which are ready for FACS assay.
Gate the OVA-TET+ CD8+ T cell group (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).

OVA TET+ CD8+ T cell counting (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Timing: 15 min

The total number of cells in the spleen (n) is counted using a Neubauer chamber or an automated cell counter (e.g., BIO-RAD TC20). And the number of OVA-TET+CD8+ T cells (N) can be calculated as N=n∗percentage of OVA-TET+CD8+ T cells (cell counting can also be performed with FACS beads).
FACS analysis of cytokine production by endogenous antigen-specific CD8+ T cells
Timing: 20 h
Staining strategy: cells are stained with APC-Cy7 anti-mouse CD8a Antibody, APC anti-mouse IFN-γ Antibody and FITC anti-human/mouse Granzyme B Antibody accordingly.
Take 50 μL splenocyte suspension and put into a 48-well.
Add 500 μL 1640 medium containing 10% FBS and antibiotics (100 Units/mL penicillin and 100 μg/mL streptomycin), and stimulate the cells with 50 ng/mL PMA and 1 μM ionomycin for 4 h in the presence of Brefeldin A (3 μg/mL) and Monensin (2 μM/L).
Collect the cells and wash twice with 500 μL PBS buffer (1200 g, 5 min).
Stain the splenocytes with APC-Cy7 anti-mouse CD8a Antibody on ice for 40 min avoid from light.
Fix and permeabilize the cells using an Intracellular Fixation & Permeabilization Buffer Set (eBioscience, Cat#88-8824-00), and the corresponding procedure is described below (Wu et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]):
Collect the cells and wash with 500 μL PBS for twice (1200 g, 5 min).
Prepare single cell suspension for each sample in a tube with 100 μL PBS .
Add 100 μL IC Fixing Buffer from the Intracellular Fixation & Permeabilization Buffer Set (eBioscience, Cat#88-8824-00) into each tube and mix gently. The mixture is then incubated at room temperature (25°C) for 20–30 min avoid exposure from light.
Add 800 μL 1× Permeabilization Buffer (diluted from the 10× Permeabilization Buffer with ddH2O) into each tube and centrifuge for 5 min at 700 g. Discard supernatant.
Repeat the step “iv”.

Stain the cells with a fluorescent dye mixture (APC anti-mouse IFN-γ and FITC anti-human/mouse Granzyme B Antibody diluted in 1× Permeabilization Buffer at 1:200, 50 μL/per sample) at 4°C 12 h–16 h.
Wash the cells with PBS twice and resuspend them with 400 μL PBS for FACS analysis.
Gate the IFN-γ+ CD8+ T cells and Granzyme B+ CD8+ T cells using Flowjo software (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
Calculate the population and the number of IFN-γ+ CD8+ T cells or Granzyme B+ CD8+ T cells (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
Critical: Membrane receptor(s) (e.g., CD8 and CD44) should be stained before fixation, because fixation may cause poor staining of a range of proteins on the membrane. All staining processes require light avoidance.

Measure L. monocytogenes titer in liver
Timing: 25 h
Weigh the isolated liver (g).
Place a 70-μm cell strainer on a 50 mL tube. Put a mouse liver on the 70-μm cell strainer with 5 mL PBS and homogenize using the rubber end of a syringe.
Flush and wash the strainer with another 5 mL PBS.

Plate 100 μL organ homogenates on BHI agar plates followed by cultured at 37°C for 24 h to determine the CFU of LmOVA on agar plates(n) (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
The titer of L. monocytogenes in liver (T) can be calculated by T = n∗100/g.

Adoptive transfer of OT-I CD8+ T cells to CD45.1 mice followed by immunization with LmOVA
We use an OT-I and CD45.1 mice adoptive transfer model to evaluate OT-I CD8+ T cell immune responses to LmOVA challenge. OT-I mice have transgenic inserts for mouse Tcra-V2 and Tcrb-V5 genes designed to recognize the OVA257–264 peptide. These mice are commonly used as a model immunological system for studying CD8+ T cell response to antigen (Clarke et al., 2000[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]; Hogquist et al., 1994[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]). CD45.1 mice are C57BL/6 congenic strain and widely used in adoptive transfer studies to track the donor and recipient cells. These mice carry the differential leukocyte marker commonly known as CD45.1, which are distinguish with C57BL/6(CD45.2) mice (Geiger et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]).
Purified OT-1 CD8+ T cells are adoptively transferred to CD45.1 mice and then the recipient mice are infected with LmOVA. The Scheme of this experiment is shown in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5].

OT-I CD8+ T cell isolation

Timing: 3 h
Collect spleens of OT-I transgenic mice aged 6–8 weeks.
Enrich CD8+ T cells by using EasySep™ Mouse Biotin Positive Selection Kit with EasySep Magnet(Other commercial isolation kits are available, e.g., Miltenyi biotec,Cat#130-104-075; and Biolegend, Cat#480035) as described below:
Put a 70 μm-cell strainer on a 50 mL centrifuge tube.
Place the spleen on the 70 μm-cell strainer and add 2 mL PBS.
Use a syringe plunger to mash the spleen on the cell strainer and wash the strainer twice with 2 mL PBS.
Collect the spleen homogenate by spinning at 400 g for 5 min at 4°C. Discard the supernatant.
Resuspend cells with 1 mL 1× Red Cell Lysis and incubate at 25°C for 5 min to eliminate red cells.
Stop the process by adding 9 mL PBS, followed by centrifuge at 400 g for 5 min.
Discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the splenocytes with 300 mL PBS + 3% FBS. Add 5 μL Biotin-CD8a (0.5 mg/mL) antibody into the tube and incubate at 25°C for 30 min.
Add 20 μL Selection cocktail from the EasySep™ Mouse Biotin Positive Selection Kit (Stem Cell, Cat#18103) to the tube and incubate at 25°C for 30 min.
Prepare the RapidSphere microbeads by Vortex.
Add 10 μL of the microbeads from the EasySep™ Mouse Biotin Positive Selection Kit (Stem Cell, Cat#18103) into sample in the tube and incubate at 25°C for 30 min.
Transfer the mixture to a 5 mL Falcon tube and place the tube on EasyEights™ EasySep™ Magnet (Stem Cell, Cat#18103) for 15 min.
Pick up the magnet, and in one continuous motion invert the magnet and tube, pouring off the supernatant. Add PBS + 3% FBS to top up the sample to 2.5 mL. Mix by gently pipetting up and down 2–3 times, and incubate for 15 min.

Repeat “xi” twice.
Pick up the magnet, and in one continuous motion invert the magnet and tube, pouring off the supernatant.
Resuspend the cells (OT-I CD8+ T cells) with a suitable volume of PBS.
Note: The purity of these cells can reach 90%–95%. Purity can be checked by FACS when using the isolation kit for the first time. In general, approximately 2–5∗106 CD8+ T cells can be obtained from the spleen of a 6–8 week old male mouse.
Critical: All procedures below are carried out in sterile conditions.
OT-I CD8+ T cell transfer
Timing: 7 days
Transplant OT-I CD8+ T cells (CD45.2+; 5 × 105 cells in 100 μL PBS/per mouse) into CD45.1+ mice by tail-vein injection.
The next day, intravenously inject 5 × 105 CFU LmOVA into each CD45.1 mouse (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
7 days later, collect the CD45.1 mouse spleen.
Place a 70 μm-cell strainer on a 50 mL centrifuge tube. Put the spleen on the cell strainer and with 2 mL PBS.
Homogenize the spleen on the cell strainer using the rubber end of a syringe.
Flush and wash the strainer with another 2 mL PBS.
Spin down the spleen homogenate at 400 g at 4°C for 10 min.
Discard the supernatant.
Lyse red cells in the suspension as we described previously.
Resuspend the supernatant with 1 mL PBS.
Stain the cells with FITC anti-mouse CD8a Antibody, APC anti-mouse CD45.1 Antibody and PE anti-mouse CD45.2 Antibody avoid exposure from light. The proportion and number of CD45.2+ CD8+ T cells can be calculated as described above (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).

Cytokine staining:
Timing: 20 h
Take 50 μL splenocyte suspension and put into a 48-well plate.
Add 500 μL 1640 medium with 10% FBS and antibiotics (100 Units/mL penicillin and 100 μg/mL streptomycin) per well and stimulate the cells with 50 ng/mL PMA and 1 μM ionomycin for 4 h in the presence of Brefeldin A (3 μg/mL) and Monensin (2 μM/L).
Stain the cells with CD8a FITC anti-mouse CD8a Antibody.
Then, fix and permeabilize the cells using an Intracellular Fixation & Permeabilization Buffer Set (eBioscience, Cat#88-8824-00) as we described in step 6(e).
Stain the cells with a fluorescent dye mixture avoid exposure from light (APC anti-mouse IFN-γ and FITC anti-human/mouse Granzyme B Antibody diluted in 1× Permeabilization Buffer at 1:200, 50 μL/per sample) at 4°C for 12 h–16 h.
Wash the cells with PBS twice and resuspend them with 400 μL PBS for FACS analysis.
Gate the IFN-γ+CD8+ T cells and Granzyme B+CD8+ T cells using Flowjo software (Figure7A[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
Calculate the population and the number of IFN-γ+CD8+ T cells or Granzyme B+ CD8+ T cells (Figure7B[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
